items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  8.03
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Cheryl King and Jamie Iseman from Jack Schreder & Associates  
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation of ESUHSD Demographic Analysis and Enrollment Projection Study
			 
			 
The Board approved and the District contracted for the professional services of Jack Schreder & Associates to conduct a Demographic Analysis and Enrollment Projection Study.  The 6 month study included an in-depth analysis of enrollment including birth data, migration rates, and charter school growth; land use, development, and planning; residency and census data along with Geographic Information System (GIS) data and spatial analysis.  The study also included a thorough analysis of facility capacity by site including future implications.  The study aimed to examine enrollment trends throughout the district for budgetary planning as well as current and future building capacity needs.  The district intends to use the study results to inform the current budget and for future facility planning efforts and considerations by the board and administration.  
			 
The Demographic Analysis and presentation are attached.   
			 
			 
Below is the link to the Demographic Analysis and Enrollment Projection Study.  Due to the large file a copy of the report is available for public view at the District Office.  A copy of the report on CD can be requested in the office of the Associate Superintendent of Business Services. 
 
https://jschreder.sharefile.com/d/s620ec7e2bc84837b

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.01
Amended
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:20 p.m. on a Charter School Renewal Petition from Escuela Popular/ Accelerated  Center for Training and Careers Family Learning Center 
	 
	 
BACKGROUND
	 
Public Charter Schools are approved initially for up to a five (5) year period and at the end of that time must apply for a charter school renewal for a term of five (5) years and continue to apply for renewal after each five (5) year term. Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within thirty (30) days following the submission of a renewal charter school petition to the district.  The renewal petition was submitted to the district on January 17, 2013.
	 
During the Public Hearing the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charter renewal within sixty (60) days of receipt of the petition; however, the date may be extended by an additional thirty (30) days if both parties agree to the extension.  Such agreement has been reached and at the March 21, 2013 Board Meeting the Governing Board shall make its determination.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE: 
Part of Review Process
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Part of Review Process
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold Public Hearing to consider level of support for the petition renewal submitted by Escuela Popular/ Accelerated  Center for Training and Careers Family Learning Center.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.02
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:25 p.m. 
Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Amended Initial Proposal for the Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to East Side Teachers Association
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association for the 2013-2014 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2013-2014 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; reduction of work year, and class size; contract language amendments to Articles 6, 7, 11, 14, 27.2, 29, 30, Appendix A and Appendix C.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any comment on the District’s amended initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:30 p.m. 
Receive and Sunshine the Initial Proposal for Successor Contract: From 
East Side Teachers Association to East Side Union High School District
	 
	 
The District has received a copy of the East Side Teachers Association’s (ESTA) initial bargaining proposal, a copy of which is attached.  Per the Government Code, the District must receive and sunshine in open session the initial proposal of any bargaining unit prior to commencing negotiations.  Administration recommends that the Board receive, sunshine, and take any public comment on the initial proposal of the East Side Teachers Association (ESTA).
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board receive, sunshine and accept any public comment on the initial proposal of the East Side Teachers Association to the East Side Union High School District.
	 
	 
	 
The East Side Teachers Association (Association) presents the following Sunshine Proposal to the East Side Union High School District (District) for the 2013-2014 school year.  
	 
The Association proposes to maintain the Collective Bargaining Agreement (CBA) language as stated in the August 22, 2008‐August 31, 2013 CBA with appropriate changes as the status quo for the 2013‐ 2014.
	 
The Association proposes the following areas for negotiation to include but not be limited to:  Class size, work year, library support, counselor to student ratio, benefits (to include co-pays), and contract amendments to Articles 11, and 29.
	 
The Association proposes the following Benefits changes:
	Maintain current VSP coverage without monthly cost to members. 
	 
Return the Kaiser Co‐pay to $5.00;
	Return the Anthem Blue Cross co‐pay to $5.00;
	Return the UAS co‐pay to $10.00. 
	 
Return the Kaiser Rx rates to $10.00/$20.00;
	Return the Anthem Blue Cross Rx rates to $10.00/$20.00;
	Return the UAS Rx rates to $10.00/$20.00 
	 
Edward L. Youngblood
	East Side Teachers Association, Bargaining Chair
	(408) 347-5692

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.03
Amendment #2
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Augment Site Improvement / Deferred Maintenance Initiative Funding for Stadium Lighting at Santa Teresa High School and Various Minor Projects
	 
	 
On November 17, 2011, the Board approved a Site Improvement/Deferred Maintenance Plan, comprised of projects focused on improving safety and security, reducing operating costs through repairing and equipping aging sites and facilities, addressing critical needs and ensuring the long term preservation and value of the District’s physical assets, and providing a clear expression of improved site conditions throughout the District.  The Board approved $32.5 million of Measure G funds for this initiative.
	 
The Administration is now requesting Board approval to allocate unencumbered Measure G funds for the Santa Teresa High School Stadium Lighting project, in an amount not to exceed $1 million. This will facilitate equity of stadium night time utilization across the District. 
	 
This authorization of $33.5 million of Measure G funding for the Site Improvement/Deferred Maintenance Initiative (previously authorized $32.5 million plus this additional $1 million) will result in a Measure G fund unencumbered balance of $11.5 million.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$1 million
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure G
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve an additional amount not to exceed $1 million of Measure G funds to be applied to the Site Improvement/Deferred Maintenance Initiative, for a combined budget of $33.5 million.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
Student A
Student B

Not Applicable

Not Applicable

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive Fourth Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering October 1st  through December 31, 2012 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CAHSEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from October 1, 2012 through December 31, 2012.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the Fourth Quarterly Valenzuela/CAHSEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering October 1, 2012 through December 31 2012, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

Item: 15.01
	  
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Receipt and/or Adoption of Second Reading of Resolution #2012/2013-16 Authorizing Election under Public Contract Code Section 22030 to Become Subject to the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) Procedures
	 
	 
The California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) is a program created in 1983 by the State Legislature, which allows local agencies to perform public project work with alternative bidding procedures that expedite public works projects, yet maintains the spirit of open accountability.
	 
A local agency that has adopted CUPCCAA may procure public works projects as follows:
	 
(a) Public projects of $45,000 or less may be performed by negotiated contract or by purchase order (PCC 22032(a)). 
(b) Public projects of $175,000 or less may be let to contract by the informal procedures set forth in the Act (PCC 22032(b)).
(c) Public projects of more than $175,000 shall be let to contract by formal bidding procedures (PCC 22032(c)). 
	 
Every five years, the Commission shall consider whether there have been material changes in public construction costs and make recommendations to the State Controller regarding adjustments to the bidding procedure monetary limits (PCC 22020).  The most recent adjustment was made by the State Controller effective July 1, 2011.
	 
CUPCCAA is a voluntary program. A local agency becomes subject to CUPCCAA by adopting a resolution to become subject to CUPCCAA and filing a copy of the resolution with the State Controller's Office (PCC 22030).  An agency may withdraw at any time by filing a resolution of this election with the State Controller's Office.  There is no cost for adoption of CUPCCAA.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the second reading of the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) and adopt Resolution #2012/2013-16 Authorizing Election under Public Contract Code Section 22030 to Become Subject to the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA).

Item: 15.02
	          
					 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion, Receipt and/or Adoption of Second Reading of Resolution #2012/2013-17 Regarding the Enacting of Informal Bidding Procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act
	 
	 
	 
The District has elected to adopt the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act procedures.  Alternative bidding procedures and certain informal bidding procedures will be implemented, in compliance with Public Contract Code 22030 et seq., for public projects of $175,000 or less.
	 
A list of contractors of the different categories of trade work that each contractor is qualified to perform shall be developed and maintained in accordance with Public Contract Code 22034.
	 
Where public projects are subject to the provisions of this policy, a notice inviting informal bids will describe the project in general terms and how to obtain more detailed information about the project, including the time and place for submission of bids.  The notice will be mailed to all contractors for the category of work to be bid as shown in the developed list of contractors, or all trade journals specified in the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Commission for Santa Clara County in accordance with section 22034 of the Public Contract Code, or both such contractors with such trade journals.  All mailing of notices to the contractors and/or trade journals described above shall be completed not less than ten (10) calendar days prior to the date that the bids are due.  Additional contractors and/or construction trade journals may be notified at the discretion of the Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and/or the Capital Projects Purchasing Manager provided that:
	 
            (1) If there is no list of qualified contractors maintained by the District for the particular category of work to be performed, the notice inviting bids shall be sent to the construction trade journals specified by the Commission and such other contractors and trade journals as the Associate Superintendent of Business Services and/or the Capital Projects Purchasing Manager may determine; and
            (2)  If the product or service is proprietary in nature such that it can be obtained only from a certain contractor or contractors, the notice inviting informal bids may be sent exclusively to such contractor or contractors.
	 
The Board of Trustees will award informal contracts pursuant to this policy.  If the lowest bid submitted by a responsible bidder exceeds $175,000, but does not exceed $187,500, the Board may nevertheless award the contract to such lowest responsible bidder if it determines, by 4/5th vote that the cost estimate of the public agency was reasonable.
	 
The Associate Superintendent of Business Services is authorized to award contract bids pursuant to the informal bidding procedures adopted by these resolutions pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 22034(e).
	 
Administration is providing the contract agreement templates that will be used for projects under $45,000 and for projects that fall under the informal bidding limit of $45,001 to $175,000.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the second reading of the enactment of informal bidding procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act and adopt Resolution #2012/2013-17 Regarding the Enacting of Informal Bidding Procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act.

Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities
SUBJECT:
Discussion and Presentation on Alternative Public Works Construction Projects Delivery Methods
		 
		 
The District’s Capital Improvement Program is a complex portfolio of projects, spanning multiple years and funded by local general obligation bond measures A, G, E and I, OPSC school facility program grants, and other minor funding streams.  A robust capital construction program of this nature should include consideration and use of a number of project delivery methods.  The program currently uses the traditional Design Bid Build delivery method exclusively, with one notable exception:  the energy efficiency project that included 8mW of solar photovoltaic arrays, interior lighting retrofits and pool pumping retrofits was delivered using an ESCO (Energy Services Contract) delivery method.
		 
While public works construction will never have the contracting flexibilities and choices of private construction, there are a number of alternative delivery methods that can supplement the traditional delivery method.  Many sophisticated and quality-oriented public entities prefer using alternative delivery methods, because those methods offer greater advantages and fewer disadvantages.  The delivery methods that will be considered for current and future projects include:
		 
Design Bid Build – Single Prime Contract
Design Bid Build – Multiple Prime Contracts
Design Build
ESCO
Lease Leaseback
		 
The District has reviewed these alternative delivery methods with legal counsel, to confirm that they are in conformance with State laws and FCMAT’s recommendations.
		 
The presentation covers these various project delivery methods, cites the enabling legislation, references previous use of those methods either at East Side or by Facilities personnel on other programs, and identifies potential upcoming projects that will be delivered using the aforementioned delivery methods.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
Not applicable
                                                                                                                          
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
Item 15.04
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action of Board Memo Format for Construction Contract Change Orders
	 
	 
	 
At its January 17, 2013 meeting, the Board of Trustees requested examples of Board memo formats for future construction contract change orders.  Change orders are a routine occurrence in construction projects.  No set of construction documents is perfectly complete and clear, there are hidden conditions that get revealed during the course of construction, and sometimes there are opportunities not previously realized for the owner to add scope to achieve a better project outcome.  There are standard protocols and procedures that govern how a contractor may propose change orders, including allowable mark up to first, second and lower tiered subcontractors and suppliers, as well as self-performed work, materials and equipment.  Potential change orders are scrutinized by the architect, construction manager, program management personnel, and the District Project Manager, and quite often are rejected as having no merit.  Once the proposed change order has been reviewed, scrutinized, negotiated and recommended for approval, the Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities approves (or rejects) it, after first ensuring that the construction contract has sufficient owner’s allowance funding to cover the cost.  When the projected exposure to potential change orders exceeds the remaining value of the owner’s allowance, District administration requests additional Board authorization in order to keep the project moving.  A work flow chart of the potential change order review and approval process is attached to this report (Attachment A).
	 
Attached for Board consideration of construction contract change order format are two examples.
Attachment B – Basic Format is District administration’s preferred format.  The format provides a project identifier (project name and number), contractor name, names of change order reviewers, school/department/manager names, fiscal impact and funding source, a statement about the conditions that caused the change order, and a contract value delineation that shows original contract amount, previously approved change orders, current proposed change order, and proposed new contract value.  
Attachment C – Detailed Format shows a format that includes the same information as Attachment B, plus additional details about the unforeseen/hidden conditions found at the construction site, owner-initiated additional work, and contractor-initiated additional fees for construction work unclearly or incorrectly shown on the construction documents.  District administration strongly discourages provision of these additional details, because it is the equivalent of showing your hand of cards at a poker game:  it reveals in a public document the details that District administration, and its agents, maintains in an exposure log that tracks construction conditions that may result in contract change orders, or that certainly will become change orders but whose prices are still being negotiated.  To reveal such information would be like providing a cheat sheet to our contractors, enabling them to maximize their change order opportunities.
	 
If Board members are interested in details of change orders, staff or construction managers are always available to meet personally to tour construction sites and discuss conditions, or to answer specific questions in person, via telephone or email.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:  
Not Applicable                                          
	                                                                               
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve Attachment B as the format for construction contract change orders.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Revoke Board Approval of Consent to Assignment and Assumption of Contracts
	 
	 
At the February 9, 2012, Regular Board Meeting, the Board approved the Assignment and Assumption of the Program Management Agreement between the District and SGI. Specifically, SGI, Program Manager for the Measure G and Measure E bond programs and also construction manager for certain on-going District capital projects, desired to assign its interests under those contracts to a new entity, SGI Construction Management, LLC, and the District, by the Board’s action, consented to the assignment.  A copy of SGI’s notice is included.  Pursuant to the program management and construction management agreements between the District and SGI, SGI is not permitted to transfer its interests under any of the contracts without the prior written consent of the Board.
	 
We have been notified by SGI that the transfer of SGI’s assets to a new entity, SGI Construction Management, LLC did not take place.  Accordingly, the Board should revoke its consent to assignment, and the District’s rights under the applicable contracts will return to the status quo.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None

Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees revoke its action taken on February 9, 2012, approving the Consent to Assignment and Assumption of Contracts between the District and SGI, and that SGI be notified of the revocation of that consent.

Discussion and/or Action for Administration to Authorize Solicitation of RFQ/P for Program Management Services for Bond Measure G, Measure E and Measure I
	 
	 
With the passage of the new Bond Measure I, the Board had previously expressed interest in opening up the solicitation process for Bond Program Management Services under Measure I.  In order to provide for economics of scale, cost-savings and consolidation of effort, Administration is recommending consideration for the consolidation of an RFQ/P for Program Management Services for Measure G, Measure E, and Measure I. 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees authorize the solicitation of RFQ/P process for Program Management Services for Bond Measure G, Measure E and Measure I.

SUBJECT:
Accept Warrant Register for the Month of January 2013
Attached is a list of warrants issued during the month of January 2013, in response to Board Policy 3314 Payment for Goods and Services adopted by the Board in May 2009.  The Policy states that, “The Board shall approve all warrants (checks) at a regularly scheduled Board meeting".  While there is no legal requirement for Board approval of issued warrants, this list and future lists will add to the “transparency” of when the Board approves purchase orders, contracts and other authorized expenses as per Board Policies.
